results.title: Nimmo St
results.brief_description: This film is a short drama with a musical soundtrack and no dialogue set around Nimmo Street in Middle Park, Melbourne. A young man meets a woman arriving on a ‘Red Rattler’ train and walks her home. On the way, they are accosted by two thugs but manage to avoid conflict. When the young woman reaches her home and doesn’t invite the man in, he leaves and takes out his frustration on the thugs when he encounters them again in the street. A simple, beautifully shot, low budget film capturing Melbourne’s inner suburban street life.

results.title: Looking at plants
results.creator_credit: Jim Harris, John Bird and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Filmed in the Sherbrooke Forest Park, Australflora Nursery, Victoria, and shows glimpses of the plant and insect life which abound there. No narration, music only.

results.title: [Black Knight]
results.brief_description: A survey of the development of the British “Black Knight” rocket test vehicle and its use in high speed flight and ballistic missile research. The elements of construction, ground support equipment, propulsion, guidance and instrumentation are discussed. Tests and launching preparations at Australia’s Woomera Range follow, closing with a night-firing sequence. NB: No opening or closing credits

results.title: Train control
results.brief_description: Shows how the movements of trains on the New South Wales railway system are controlled to ensure smooth running and prevent accidents. When the system has been explained, its working is illustrated by tracing the journey of a goods train from one point to another.

results.title: Darwin's body snatchers
results.creator_credit: Chris Oxley, Channel 4, U K and Laurel Productions
results.brief_description: This program looks at the export trade in Aboriginal skeletons, skulls and body parts rife during the nineteenth century and which continued up until 1940. Anthropologists and museums influenced by the work of Charles Darwin sought these remains for scientific study and museum exhibition. Australian doctors, scientists and supposedly respectable citizens may have colluded in both grave robbing and “killing to order”, to fulfil the European demand for the supply of Aboriginal bodies, which were treated as commodities. The program looks at shifts in museum policy and the efforts by groups such as the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre to have these remains repatriated from overseas institutions back to Australia for proper burial by their descendants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Oxley, Channel 4, U K and Laurel Productions

results.title: A Place Called Mooroopna
results.creator_credit: John Richardson, Adrian Boddington and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: Documents a young Scottish migrant’s arrival to Melbourne and his subsequent journey with his new found Aussie mate around Australia. They visit Portsea and travel through various country areas of Victoria finally stopping at Mooroopna when their car breaks down. The Scotsman gets a job at Mooroopna in the local Ardmona Fruit Cannery for the season. The film shows the making of cans and the processing and canning of the peach and pear crops.

results.title: RAAF Newsreel. No. 9. Operation sabre ferry
results.creator_credit: Harry Rayner and Australia. Royal Australian Air Force
results.brief_description: Newsreel items including: 1. No. 3 Squadron and No. 77 Squadron of the RAAF ferry the Sabre Jet from the east coast of Australia to Butterworth in Malaya via Townsville, Darwin, Netherlands New Guinea, Philippines, Borneo, Malaya. 2. Firefighter - RAAF demonstrates capability of new firefighting truck. 3. Addition of the new Air to Air Missile to the Sabre Jet Fighter. Test fired at Woomera.

results.title: [The Australian outback]
results.brief_description: On a cattle station 200 miles from Oodnadatta, stockmen are shown preparing for a muster, mustering scrub cattle, branding and droving the cattle to the trucking yards.
